#Text=Yakov Bukhvostov
#Text=The Dormition Cathedral in Ryazan , built by Bukhvostov between 1693 and 1699

#Text=Yakov Grigorievich Bukhvostov ( Russian : Яков Григорьевич Бухвостов ) , a serf of Russian boyar Mikhail Tatishchev , designed the so-called " octagon on cube " churches in the Naryshkin Baroque mode .

column1: #Text=He was active in the 1690s in Moscow and Ryazan , where he supervised the construction of the new Dormition Cathedral in the kremlin .
#Text=His tower churches in Ubory and Troitse-Lykovo " may owe something to prototypes in wooden Russian architecture " . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=They are built of brick and decorated with profuse white stone ornamentation .
#Text=A soaring white tower in front of New Jerusalem Monastery was also built from Bukhvostov 's designs .
#Text=Other buildings attributed to him include the Fili and Zyuzino churches .
#Text=Some of the attributions are far fetched , since " there is documentary evidence of his being in charge of constructing only a handful of buildings " . [ 2 ]
#Text=Traditional account of Bukhvostov 's activities
#Text=The biography of Bukhvostov is largely unknown .
#Text=He was a serf assigned to the village of Nikolskoe-Sverchkovo , close to Dmitrov , which belonged to Tatishchev boyars .
#Text=He was first mentioned by reliable sources in 1690 , when he won a concession to build monk cells in the Moiseev Monastery in Moscow ( the monastery was later demolished ) .
#Text=After completing the cells Bukhvostov , with his people , started the construction of walls and towers of the New Jerusalem Monastery in present-day Istra .
#Text=The walls and towers of the monastery bear almost no decoration , something which is not typical for Bukhvostov 's style .
#Text=The only exception is the Church of the Entry to Jerusalem built on the top of one of the gates .
#Text=This church was apparently started by Bukhvostov , but completed by Filipp Papuga and brothers Leonty and Emelyan Mikhaylov , using Bukhvostov 's plans .
#Text=The Church of the Holy Mandylion in Ubory , constructed between 1698 and 1704

#Text=In December 1692 , when the construction of the New Jerusalem monastery was still under-way , Bukhvostov obtained a concession to build The Assumption ( Dormition ) cathedral in Ryazan , where the old cathedral had collapsed .
#Text=Very soon afterwards Bukhvostov got a commission from a boyar , Pyotr Sheremetev , to build the Church of the Holy Mandylion in the village of Ubory , close to Moscow .
#Text=He failed to complete the church within two years , a requirement of the contract , and Sheremetev asked the authorities to place Bukhvostov under arrest .
#Text=Under the imminent threat of arrest , Bukhvostov struck a deal with Sheremetev to complete the church in 1696 .
#Text=When he failed to do this either , Sheremetev had him arrested , but then realized that the church would never be completed with Bukhvostov in jail and asked the authorities to release him .
#Text=The church in Ubory was completed in 1697 , although Sheremetev was already dead .
#Text=Bukhvostov completed the Assumption cathedral in Ryazan during 1699 and went on to construct a number of churches in the same city .
#Text=None of these churches have survived into this century .
#Text=His last documented work ( 1698 — 1704 ) is the Trinity Church in Troitse-Lykovo , now within the city limits of Moscow .
#Text=No details of the architect 's later life survived .
#Text=Oeuvres
#Text=The Holy Trinity Church in Troitse-Lykovo , 1698 — 1704
#Text=The following buildings have been documented as having been constructed by Bukhvostov and his associates :
#Text=The walls and towers of the New Jerusalem Monastery , including the Church of the Entry to Jerusalem , 1690 — 1697 .
#Text=Destroyed in World War II , subsequently restored .
#Text=The Church of the Holy Mandylion in Ubory , 1694 — 1697 .
#Text=The Assumption ( Dormition ) Cathedral in Ryazan , 1693 — 1699 .
#Text=The Holy Trinity Church in Troitse-Lykovo , 1698 — 1704 .

#Text=Besides these four , a number of churches somewhat similar in style have been attributed to Bukhvostov in some non-specialist literature , without any documented sources , just on the basis of the comparison of the style .
#Text=These include :
#Text=John the Baptist and Saint Spirit churches in the Solotcha monastery , close to Ryazan . [ 3 ]
#Text=The Church of Saints Boris and Gleb in Zyuzino , now in Moscow . [ 4 ]
#Text=The Church of the Intercession at Fili , now in Moscow . [ 5 ]
